VOL. XVII, NO. 10.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 9, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

TRACK ORGANIZATION MEETING

BARONESS VON SUTTNER-HERE

LACROSSE MEN TO MEET

An Enthusiastic Meeting Held at the
City Club, in Gotham—Annual
Dinner Arrangements.

Good Crowd of Men Gather in Trophy
• Room—Hard Schedule Ahead—Relay Team This Year.

Austrian Noblewoman Addresses the
Maryland Peace Society—President
Remsen Presides at Meeting.

Organization Tuesday in Trophy Room.
Huck, ,Schmeisser, Raleigh, Wolfe,
Lowndes and Hulburt to Speak.

One of the best attended and
most enthusiastic meetings of the
New York Alumni took place Friday, December 6, at the City Club
of New York.
Participation in the important
measures introduced at the meeting
was general. The Association resolved to hold its annual dinner between the first of January ,and the
fifteenth of February next, at which
the invited guests are to be the
President of the University, the
President of the Board of Trustees,
Ambassador Bryce and Presidentelect Wilson. A special committee
of arrangements was appointed,
consisting of Professor Franklin,.
Professor Hyslop, Mr. Abraham
Flexner and Mr. H. L. Gantt. The
Society next took up the question
of procuring permanent headquarters. That the time waS ripe for
such a move was indicated by the
fact that no less than three distinct workable •• plans were proposed. The Chair appointed a
committee, consisting of Robert H.
Grimes, 'William I.6Guard, Donald
M. Liddell, Norvin Lindheim, Dr.
E. M. Pease and Milton Erlanger,
to report upon the matter at the
next meeting and with authority to
call a general meeting of the Association •in the interval to get the
views of all the members.
Mr. Tuska reported upon the
"Who's Who at the Johns Hopkins
University," Which has been undertaken under the auspices of the
New York Alumni and designed
to be the gift of that body on the
occasion of the removal of the University to Homewood. It was estimated that the .cost of preparing
the catalogue would be in the
neighborhood of $1,500, which
amount is to be underwritten by
private subscription. Mr. Thomas
R. Ball, the registrar of the University, was expected to have been
present as a guest of the New Yot*
Alumni and to have reported upon
the details of the proposed work
involving as it does the cataloguing of, and statistics with respect
to, no less than 7,000 persons who
at one time or another had been
enrolled in the University. His
letters upon this subject were read
and universal regret was expressed
that our old friend found that work
in Baltimore prevented him from
being with us.
About seventy letters to former
students upon the New York list
having been returned "not found,"
Dr. Gould, the president, read the

In line with the enthusiasm displayed in the football season, was
the big turn out for the track organization, last Tuesday in the
Trophy Room. Captain Catlin called
the meeting to order at five o'clock,
with all the seats in the room occupied. He explained to the new
men that many of last season's
stars had graduated, giving the
new men an exceptionally fine
chance to show what they can do.
He then explained that the training would consist of gymnasium
work three days in the week,
with one day in the cage. After
Christmas there will probably be
more work on the cage track than
this month. Manager Carter announced three dates as definitely
fixed, with several dual meets pending. Notable among these are
pending meets with Princeton and
the University of Virginia.- -2 mong
the other speakers were "Freddie"
Lee, "Jack" Fulton, Evelyth Bridgman, "Joe" England and Gilbert
Horrax.
Track enthusiasts will be glad to
hear that Hopkins will have a relay
team, which will enter the Pennsylvania meet, besides cdmpeting
with other colleges who have challenged the Black and Blue in the
past.
No coach has .been selected as
yet, but the alumni advisers, Mr.
Theodore Straus and Dr. George
A. Stewart, will Probably announce
their selection this week. The sophomore-freshman meet is to be
held on Saturday, January 18, in
the cage. As there are more than
fifteen freshmen who are candidates
for the team, the "sophs" will have
to wake up, unless they want a
severe beating.
The candidates who have signed
up for the track team squad are:
Lloyd, Wells, Iddings, Stiebel, Ludington, Castleman, Watkins,Jacobs,
Spencer, Biscr, Baroway, Deems,
Brown, Tull, Horrax,Reeside, Ray,
Tarr, C. I. Uhler, Snyder, Lee,
George Penniman, Buchness, Merrick, Victdr Bridgman, Connolly,
Wood, Evitt, Hayes, Baer, Melamet, Knipp and Catlin.

The division of honors between
preparatory school graduates and
high schtiol graduates in athletics
and in the lecture room, form the
same general ratio at Hopkins as
at other universities. The preparatory .school men receive a majority
of 'Varsity -11's," but on the other
hand the public school men stand
first in scholarship.
The following statistics have been
compiled exclusively from the 18o
men in the collegiate department
during the academic year of 191112. Of that number 70 men came
from private schools and the remaining 110 from public schools,
a ratio of 7:ii.- Now there were
29 undergraduates who had received scholarships, Phi Beta Kappa
keys or honorable mention, and
of these only 8 men from private
schools, against 21 from public
schools. This ratio of 8:21 in comparison with the ratio of 7:mi total
enrollment, shows the superiority
of the students from the public
schools at their university work.
Thirty-five men wore the 'Varsity
-H" last year, of which 17 were
from private schools, 16 from public schools, a ratio of 17:16. Again,
comparing this with the ratio of
7
total enrollment, it turns out
that the private school men have
more "H's" than the public school
men in spite of the inverse ratio
of their numbers.
One does not have to look far
for an explanation of these facts.
At many private schools a good
season in athletics, especially football, will draw a number of new
boys the next fall. It is a natural
result, not only in private schools,
but at universities where the athletic standing is high ; and it turns
out that an athletic team is a very
good advertisement for the headmaster, and he encourages the
sport. Now at the public schools,
though their teams often excell, no
stress is put on a boy to spend his
time on the athletic field. His
main purpose is to study, and he
does the same when he conies to
college.
Legal Verbosity.

An old Missouri deed for forty
acres of land is a good illustration
of legal verbiage. It conveys "all
and singular-appurtenances,appendages, advow sons, benefits, commons, curtilages, cowhouses, corn
cribs, dairies, dovecotes, easements,
emoluments, freeholds, features,
furniture, fixtures, gardens, homestalls, improvements, immunities,
limekilns, meadows, marshes, mines,
minerals, orchards, parks, pleasure
grounds, pigeon houses, pigstyes,
quarries, remainders, reversions,
rents, rights, ways, water courses,
wind-mills, together with every
other necessary right, immunitie,
privilege and advantage of whatsoever name, nature or description."

THI.: NEWS-LETTER wishes to announce the election of Mr. L. L.
Jacobs, '13, to the position of assistant business manager.
Examinations and the Holidays.

Beulah Land lies beyond the darkness and terrors of the Valley of
the Shadow of Death; the golden
'apples of the Hesperides are to be
reached only by eluding the fangs
of an ever-watchful and ever-hungry dragon; and with these consolations more than one bold sophomore—for all his boldness still,
alas, so pitifully new, to the ways
of college—is undoubtedly trying
to persuade himself just now that
it is only natural and proper that
the bliss of the Christmas holidays
should be preceded by a more or
less trying period of anguish and
bloody sweat—the examinations.

LEMMERT

A University and the People.

The large number of meetings
held in McCoy Hall during the last
few weeks by various societies for
social and civic betterment serve
• to remind us of the way in which
the University is discharging one
of the important duties of an institution of learning. To train and
develop its scholars is only the immediate end of such an institution's
existence; its ultimate end is the
improvement of the condition of
humanity, and this is to be accomplished not only by the training of a limited number of young
men, but in manifold other ways
which present themselves from time
to time. Its realization of this fact
the University has repeatedly displayed by its rea0iness at all times
to lend its hospitality and influence
to improvement organizations of all
kinds. Not only are good causes thus
given valuable assistance, but a result of even greater importance is
that the University's real aim is
in this way made clear to the public at large as it could not be in
any other way, its efforts are consequently more likely to be appreciated, and its influence more likely
to be effective. A university wants
to make it clear to the people that
beneath its incomprehensible scientific and literary activity lies a perfectly Comprehensible motive—a desire to improve the community, the
State and the nation. By entertaining such organizations as the Visiting Nurses' Association and the
Federated Charities, to say nothing
of the American Penologists and
the Maryland Peace Society, it
enunciates this aim as clearly as
corporate body can:
A pair of hazel eyes I know
With glances fond for me:
Two outstretched arms, two rosy lips,
A vision rare to see.
Those hazel eyes, those arms outstretched,
Those lips which I claim mine
Are always present to my view,
They're painted on my stein.
—Wesleyan Literary Monthly.

Wants a Respite.

DEcE1m•3z 3, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—Once more the time
for the examinations is fast approaching, and I am making bold
to bring up, once niore, the old,
old subject. The question is this:
Why are the students not granted
a day before the examinations free
from recitations or lectures? This
year the examinations begin on
Tuesday, the 17th. What objection can the faculty have to giving
us freedom on the 16th? We cannot prepare for examinations and
keep up with daily recitations at
the same time. One or the other
must suffer. We all need more or
less preparation to do creditably in
the examinations, but this preparation is always hindered by having
daily lessons up to the night before
the first examination. The loss of
a lecture or two would be slight,
indeed, and the advantage far
greater, if all work would be suspended on Friday the 13th. I am
not -alone in this position, and I
sincerely hope the faculty will give
the matter due consideration.

Women's Civic League.

Last Friday afternoon, at 3.30
o'clock, the Women's Civic League
of Baltimore met in the Donovan
Room. The president of the League,
Mrs. Benjamin Corkran, called the
meeting to order and introduced as
the principal speaker the Honorable James H. Preston, Mayor of
Baltimore.
The Mayor spoke for an hour,
before the seventy-five women present, on the "Budget of the Year."
He explained the personnel, the
working, and the duties of the
Board of Estimates, telling how
they calculate the estimates at the
City Hall. Mayor Preston declared
that it was not his chief duty to
"float" loans, and from "a memoranda" which he read, he declared
that there was no telling how important these funds "might be in
the past," after he has given up his
place to his "predecessor." He
then went into detail in regard to
the problems of making up this
year's budget.
After Mayor Preston's speech,
City Solicitor Field gave a brief
but interesting talk, explaining some
of the provisions of the present
City Charter and their relation to
the civic work which the Women's
Civic League, is seeking to accomplish.

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 9,

9

1912,

FIRST COTILLON OF SEASON
McCoy Hall the Scene of Gay Gowns
and Dignified Dress Suits An
Enjoyable Affair.

.11

Last Friday night McCoy Hall
was the scene of gay gowns and
dignified dress suits, and the sombre walls, used mostly to sober
lectures, vibrated to the tune of the
"Count of Luxemburg" and "Waiting for the Robert E. Lee." The
Cotillon Club was holding the first
dance of the-season. A larger number of undergraduate students than
usual were present, and the graduate and medical departments ,had
a full number of representatives.
Many of the faculty members and
their wives, also attended.
The Cotillon Board, at the suggestion of Dr. Magoffin, had decided to reintroduce a receiving line
into the formalities of the dance.
At each dance, the wives of the
different members of the faculty
will be asked to receive. For the
first cotillon, those asked, were
Mrs. Ira Remsen, Mrs. R. V. D.
Magoffin, Mrs. Blanchard Randall,
Mrs. Kirby F. Smith and Mrs. J. B.
•Watson. The receiving line gave
the dance an added dignity and
formality.
Before .nine o'clock, two rooms
on the second floor, those that
usually are frequented by the lovers
of Goethe and Horace, were filled
with the buzz of female voices and
the scent of powder. The basement was devoted to the ladies' escorts, and there, before Walter's
mirrors, they brushed a stray hair
into place or straightened a stubborn necktie. At nine o'clock the
doors of McCoy Hall were opened
and the receiving line stood in place
while Messrs. Donoho and Leland
of the Cotillon Board introduced
the ladies and gentlemen who had
in the meantime congregated in
front of the Donovan Room. After
a short space of informal dancing,
the first dance began.
During the intermissions the
(lancers promenaded in the corridors, or went outside at the Druid
Hill avenue entrance into the cool
air, or visited the punch bowl. At
the supper intermission groups
gathered here and there, many even
sitting on the broad stairs ascending from the Donovan Room, while
the waiters hustled up and down
the basement stairs, hurrying with
the salad and cream that were already delayed. After a short time,
when the strains of "Sumurun
Girl" proceeded from the palms on
the platform in McCoy Hall, the
groups dwindled, and the dancing
floor again held its own. At twelve
o'clock the "Quaker Girl," followed
as an encore by the "Robert E.
Lee" and "Home, Sweet Home,"
closed the first cotillon.
The Cotillon Board is composed
of the following: Edmond S. Donoho, James H. 'Marston, Charles
Ellis Ellicott, J. Earle Uhler, all
of the '13 class; Guy Hollyday and
Frank K. Leland, of the '14 class,
and Allen F. Voshell, of the '15
class.

One of the best attended and
most enthusiastic meetings of the
New York Alumni took place Friday, December 6, at the City Club
of New York.
Participation in the important
measures introduced at the meeting
was general. The Association resolved to hold its annual dinner between the first of January ,and the
fifteenth of February next, at which
the invited guests are to be the
President of the University, the
President of the Board of Trustees,
Ambassador Bryce and Presidentelect Wilson. A special committee
of arrangements was appointed,
consisting of Professor Franklin,.
Professor Hyslop, Mr. Abraham
Flexner and Mr. H. L. Gantt. The
Society next took up the question
of procuring permanent headquarters. That the time waS ripe for
such a move was indicated by the
fact that no less than three distinct workable •• plans were proposed. The Chair appointed a
committee, consisting of Robert H.
Grimes, 'William I.6Guard, Donald
M. Liddell, Norvin Lindheim, Dr.
E. M. Pease and Milton Erlanger,
to report upon the matter at the
next meeting and with authority to
call a general meeting of the Association •in the interval to get the
views of all the members.
Mr. Tuska reported upon the
"Who's Who at the Johns Hopkins
University," Which has been undertaken under the auspices of the
New York Alumni and designed
to be the gift of that body on the
occasion of the removal of the University to Homewood. It was estimated that the .cost of preparing
the catalogue would be in the
neighborhood of $1,500, which
amount is to be underwritten by
private subscription. Mr. Thomas
R. Ball, the registrar of the University, was expected to have been
present as a guest of the New Yot*
Alumni and to have reported upon
the details of the proposed work
involving as it does the cataloguing of, and statistics with respect
to, no less than 7,000 persons who
at one time or another had been
enrolled in the University. His
letters upon this subject were read
and universal regret was expressed
that our old friend found that work
in Baltimore prevented him from
being with us.
About seventy letters to former
students upon the New York list
having been returned "not found,"

The division of honors between
preparatory school graduates and
high schtiol graduates in athletics
and in the lecture room, form the
same general ratio at Hopkins as
at other universities. The preparatory .school men receive a majority
of 'Varsity -11's," but on the other
hand the public school men stand
first in scholarship.
The following statistics have been
compiled exclusively from the 18o
men in the collegiate department
during the academic year of 191112. Of that number 70 men came
from private schools and the remaining 110 from public schools,
a ratio of 7:ii.- Now there were
29 undergraduates who had received scholarships, Phi Beta Kappa
keys or honorable mention, and
of these only 8 men from private
schools, against 21 from public
schools. This ratio of 8:21 in comparison with the ratio of 7:mi total
enrollment, shows the superiority
of the students from the public
schools at their university work.
Thirty-five men wore the 'Varsity
-H" last year, of which 17 were
from private schools, 16 from public schools, a ratio of 17:16. Again,
comparing this with the ratio of
7
total enrollment, it turns out
that the private school men have
more "H's" than the public school
men in spite of the inverse ratio
of their numbers.
One does not have to look far
for an explanation of these facts.
At many private schools a good
season in athletics, especially football, will draw a number of new
boys the next fall. It is a natural
result, not only in private schools,
but at universities where the athletic standing is high ; and it turns
out that an athletic team is a very
good advertisement for the headmaster, and he encourages the
sport. Now at the public schools,
though their teams often excell, no
stress is put on a boy to spend his
time on the athletic field. His
main purpose is to study, and he
does the same when he conies to
college.

LEMMERT

A University and the People.

The large number of meetings
held in McCoy Hall during the last
few weeks by various societies for
social and civic betterment serve
• to remind us of the way in which
the University is discharging one
of the important duties of an institution of learning. To train and
develop its scholars is only the immediate end of such an institution's
existence; its ultimate end is the
improvement of the condition of
humanity, and this is to be accomplished not only by the training of a limited number of young
men, but in manifold other ways
which present themselves from time
to time. Its realization of this fact
the University has repeatedly displayed by its rea0iness at all times
to lend its hospitality and influence
to improvement organizations of all
kinds. Not only are good causes thus
given valuable assistance, but a result of even greater importance is
that the University's real aim is
in this way made clear to the public at large as it could not be in
any other way, its efforts are consequently more likely to be appreciated, and its influence more likely
to be effective. A university wants
to make it clear to the people that
beneath its incomprehensible scientific and literary activity lies a perfectly Comprehensible motive—a desire to improve the community, the
State and the nation. By entertaining such organizations as the Visiting Nurses' Association and the
Federated Charities, to say nothing
of the American Penologists and
the Maryland Peace Society, it
enunciates this aim as clearly as
corporate body can:
A pair of hazel eyes I know
With glances fond for me:
Two outstretched arms, two rosy lips,
A vision rare to see.
Those hazel eyes, those arms outstretched,
Those lips which I claim mine
Are always present to my view,
They're painted on my stein.
—Wesleyan Literary Monthly.

Wants a Respite.

DEcE1m•3z 3, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—Once more the time
for the examinations is fast approaching, and I am making bold
to bring up, once niore, the old,
old subject. The question is this:
Why are the students not granted
a day before the examinations free
from recitations or lectures? This
year the examinations begin on
Tuesday, the 17th. What objection can the faculty have to giving
us freedom on the 16th? We cannot prepare for examinations and
keep up with daily recitations at
the same time. One or the other
must suffer. We all need more or
less preparation to do creditably in
the examinations, but this preparation is always hindered by having
daily lessons up to the night before
the first examination. The loss of
a lecture or two would be slight,
indeed, and the advantage far
greater, if all work would be suspended on Friday the 13th. I am
not -alone in this position, and I
sincerely hope the faculty will give
the matter due consideration.

Women's Civic League.

Last Friday afternoon, at 3.30
o'clock, the Women's Civic League
of Baltimore met in the Donovan
Room. The president of the League,
Mrs. Benjamin Corkran, called the
meeting to order and introduced as
the principal speaker the Honorable James H. Preston, Mayor of
Baltimore.
The Mayor spoke for an hour,
before the seventy-five women present, on the "Budget of the Year."
He explained the personnel, the
working, and the duties of the
Board of Estimates, telling how
they calculate the estimates at the
City Hall. Mayor Preston declared
that it was not his chief duty to
"float" loans, and from "a memoranda" which he read, he declared
that there was no telling how important these funds "might be in
the past," after he has given up his
place to his "predecessor." He
then went into detail in regard to
the problems of making up this
year's budget.
After Mayor Preston's speech,
City Solicitor Field gave a brief
but interesting talk, explaining some
of the provisions of the present
City Charter and their relation to
the civic work which the Women's
Civic League, is seeking to accomplish.

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 9,

9

1912,

FIRST COTILLON OF SEASON
McCoy Hall the Scene of Gay Gowns
and Dignified Dress Suits An
Enjoyable Affair.

.11

Last Friday night McCoy Hall
was the scene of gay gowns and
dignified dress suits, and the sombre walls, used mostly to sober
lectures, vibrated to the tune of the
"Count of Luxemburg" and "Waiting for the Robert E. Lee." The
Cotillon Club was holding the first
dance of the-season. A larger number of undergraduate students than
usual were present, and the graduate and medical departments ,had
a full number of representatives.
Many of the faculty members and
their wives, also attended.
The Cotillon Board, at the suggestion of Dr. Magoffin, had decided to reintroduce a receiving line
into the formalities of the dance.
At each dance, the wives of the
different members of the faculty
will be asked to receive. For the
first cotillon, those asked, were
Mrs. Ira Remsen, Mrs. R. V. D.
Magoffin, Mrs. Blanchard Randall,
Mrs. Kirby F. Smith and Mrs. J. B.
•Watson. The receiving line gave
the dance an added dignity and
formality.
Before .nine o'clock, two rooms
on the second floor, those that
usually are frequented by the lovers
of Goethe and Horace, were filled
with the buzz of female voices and
the scent of powder. The basement was devoted to the ladies' escorts, and there, before Walter's
mirrors, they brushed a stray hair
into place or straightened a stubborn necktie. At nine o'clock the
doors of McCoy Hall were opened
and the receiving line stood in place
while Messrs. Donoho and Leland
of the Cotillon Board introduced
the ladies and gentlemen who had
in the meantime congregated in
front of the Donovan Room. After
a short space of informal dancing,
the first dance began.
During the intermissions the
(lancers promenaded in the corridors, or went outside at the Druid
Hill avenue entrance into the cool
air, or visited the punch bowl. At
the supper intermission groups
gathered here and there, many even
sitting on the broad stairs ascending from the Donovan Room, while
the waiters hustled up and down
the basement stairs, hurrying with
the salad and cream that were already delayed. After a short time,
when the strains of "Sumurun
Girl" proceeded from the palms on
the platform in McCoy Hall, the
groups dwindled, and the dancing
floor again held its own. At twelve
o'clock the "Quaker Girl," followed
as an encore by the "Robert E.
Lee" and "Home, Sweet Home,"
closed the first cotillon.
The Cotillon Board is composed
of the following: Edmond S. Donoho, James H. 'Marston, Charles
Ellis Ellicott, J. Earle Uhler, all
of the '13 class; Guy Hollyday and
Frank K. Leland, of the '14 class,
and Allen F. Voshell, of the '15
class.
